timeline.message: Upload partial non-confidential Dropwizard yml file
Fix some deprecated GitHub library accessors

timeline.bodyText: For my understanding, the other confidential files like config_file, confidential1_1.5.0 are being expanded out to their final locations?
timeline.author: denis-yuen
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,13 +1,20 @@
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
-# This script decrypts our test database 
-# WARNING: Edit decrypt.template.mustache not decrypt.sh which is a generated file
+# This script decrypts our test database
 # Bash3 Boilerplate. Copyright (c) 2014, kvz.io
+# You will need the environment variables CIRCLE_CI_KEY and CIRCLE_CI_IV
 
 set -o errexit
 set -o pipefail
 set -o nounset
 set -o xtrace
 
-openssl aes-256-cbc -K $encrypted_f3e772af0e32_key -iv $encrypted_f3e772af0e32_iv -in secrets.tar.enc -out secrets.tar -d
+: "$CIRCLE_CI_KEY"
+: "$CIRCLE_CI_IV"
+
+openssl aes-256-cbc -d -in circle_ci_test_data.zip.enc -k "$CIRCLE_CI_KEY" -iv "$CIRCLE_CI_IV" -out secrets.tar
 tar xvf secrets.tar

replies.bodyText: everything will go to the right location auto-magically. What happened before was we flattened it structurally into the archive. and then we unflattened it in the expand script. Now it just doesn't do any of that.
replies.author: garyluu

timeline.bodyText:
The old approach had different keys when a new confidential bundle was uploaded.
What is the strategy when someone wants to work on a new bundle in a branch but other builds need to use the old bundle?
timeline.author: denis-yuen
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,13 +1,20 @@

-# This script decrypts our test database 
-# WARNING: Edit decrypt.template.mustache not decrypt.sh which is a generated file
+# This script decrypts our test database
 # Bash3 Boilerplate. Copyright (c) 2014, kvz.io
+# You will need the environment variables CIRCLE_CI_KEY and CIRCLE_CI_IV
 
 set -o errexit
 set -o pipefail
 set -o nounset

-openssl aes-256-cbc -K $encrypted_f3e772af0e32_key -iv $encrypted_f3e772af0e32_iv -in secrets.tar.enc -out secrets.tar -d

replies.bodyText:
The old approach had different keys when a new confidential bundle was uploaded.
What is the strategy when someone wants to work on a new bundle in a branch but other builds need to use the old bundle?

I was wondering why the zip file had a folder in it, and I had suggested to Gary in another PR comment to remove it. But actually, I still don't get it. When files are extracted from the zip, they are extracted relative from the folder into your local file system. So if I were switching between branches, I would have two zip files, one for each branch, and extract from the appropriate one.
I feel like I'm missing something.
replies.author: coverbeck

replies.bodyText: Ya, I don't get the issue. One bundle for each branch. Just run bash decrypt.sh again
replies.author: garyluu

replies.bodyText: I think the piece I was missing is that all branches are using the same key, so all bundles can be decrypted using the same key + iv value.
replies.author: denis-yuen
